titleStmt.title: CW 111
titleStmt.author: Carmichael, Alexander Archibald (1832‐1912)
titleStmt.sponsor: Edinburgh University Library and the Department of Scottish and Celtic Studies

interpretation.p: All digital surrogates of the original source are linked with the markup textfile.
All Gaelic (and some English) texts have an English summary, keywords, and, where applicable, a taxonomic reference.
For some Gaelic (and English) texts a bibliographic reference(s) will be provided to printed texts.

correction.p: Errors from the original source transcription have been kept to a minimum by employing a double re‐keying method when typed out. In addition, all re‐keyed texts have been proof‐read by the text editors.

A guiding principle of the Alexander Carmichael notebooks markup procedure is to approximate the original document as closely as possible, so that the character of Carmichael's transcriptions is preserved along with its content. XML (eXtensible Markup Language), with its capacity to convey emendations such as deletions (crossed out) and supralinear additions and so forth, can digitally reproduce an authentic version which reflects the source documents.
Where authorial changes, e.g. substitution, have occurred in the text then this has been annotated.
All words have been retained as written in the source text even when there are apparent errors in either spelling or when there has been either an omission in punctuation or grammar.

In such cases missing words or letters have not been supplied. Quotation marks and other missing grammatical marks have not been supplied. Where there are gaps in the text usually because the word was inaudible (some background noise, perhaps) or where the transcriber could not make out what was being said in the act of transcription (perhaps the speaker was inarticulate or mumbling or for whatever reason) then these have been tagged, though not explained; where a word is now difficult, illegible or just unclear, then this has also been tagged.
All such changes have been annotated in accordance with TEI 5 procedures.

normalization.p: No normalization of the words such as changing the source text to conform with current Gaelic orthographic conventions has been undertaken. The texts are as given with only minor editorial changes. in order to preserve the integrity of the original texts.

quotation.p: All opening quotation marks, hyphens, dashes, apostrophes, periods, colons, etc. have been retained in the source text and have been encoded in accodance with ISO entity references, etc.
All double marks have been processed using straight quotation marks, that is, ". All single quotation marks have been rendered using apostrophe.

hyphenation.p: End‐of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.

segmentation.p: Folio numbers have been added in pencil at the top of each notebook page are retained using the pb (pagebreak) element together with the n attribute for the page number and the ed attribute to specify the edition.
When an tale‐text or song which, more often than not, fills more than one page, it is segmented with page break.

A reference system has been built up using the identifiers of the following text units: text, division, paragraph. Each nested division has an identifier which is built up by successively adding to the identifier of the text. Each paragraph has an identifier which adds yet another layer to the immediately superordinate identifier.

langUsage.language: Approximately 95% of the texts are Scottish Gaelic, 2.5% of the texts are in Irish Gaelic and the remainder being roughly divided between English and Scots.

change.item: Added new Encoding and Profile Descriptions
Proof-read and made corrections to file

div.p:
Submerged Church –
from Ken.Kennethneth MacKenzie mason
Dallabrog at Eriskay Barra 4 NovNovember
1873 –

Below Bornish Uarach & side
of point lowest of spring tide
the best tide. I was shearing
& usgusing a sharp stone An old hdhand
said to me if you were at Caib
eal Mhic Ceallaich. "Where?
past below yon. Search & find
a buildgbuilding with door & 1 side archarched 20 ininchesches
visible freestone rebut. half inch
bead abtabout 4 inchinches back frfrom edge of corner
and an inch juniper on the face
Wall 21 inchinches thick & ap.appears to be a door
There was no bay inside such as a
window wldwould have – The upupper end of the
arch ap.appears to be ababout 15 in.inches fr.from the Key
Gothic arch. Door ap.appears abt.about 2½ ftfeet wiwith
real gothic. Juniper is wherwhere
edge is cut awyaway. Built of lime
& mosslayers inside small & far
larger stones outoutside. Wall covercovered over
with tangles large staimh. I tore
off these for 7 ftfeet of all. There
was more wall but this was
all I bare. rubble filled up the
wall to near top. 200 yrdsyards out frfrom
the tiura. When I saw the beautbeautiful
work so beautbeautiful done I had not
the heart to touch it. HerHere oth-other
rebuts seemed to have been
taken away. This was abtabout 30
yrsyears ago. in Augt.August. On s.south side of
Ruairdvaoilein nearer
Bornish than Kildonan
Caibeal Mhic CheallMhic Cheallaich also
at Dallabrog. MacCeallan
requestrequested to be buried as low as
the tide went out & a caib.caibeal
about him. But how was
soft lime to solidify?

My sons brobrought home some bits
of the masonry of the caibeal
at Dallabrog.

Mrs Martin Dallabrog (Allan
her son also) knows all the
sub-marsub-marine-places
Kil pheadKil pheadair is under
the sea – It is not seen
now but another.

lg.l: "I turned my dipper hook aside
And spared the symbol dear."

div.p:
Hoilisgeir
Remains of house eye of Kiln
& fire place (sorn) & dyke on top of
Pabby Harris 50 acres lost
Lime on ruins at Kildonan
Mrs MacgillyMacGillvray saw it when
a lassie with tangles sticking to it

Cook at Milton prstpresent now who knows
it. Her fathfather had a house right above
the place.

Trad.Tradition says that the sea inside isle of
Circeabost Baileshear etc was a
taklake or series of lakes till the sea broke in
the divdivide. Houses seen under the
sea s.south side of KirkKirkibost –

Cornwall – Mount's Bay. sunk
much. saw this when visiting St.
Michaels' Mount. See Johnsons
remarks about Coll.

Macdonald sistsister of TormTormod
Mac Uilleam Buidhe Barra find her
out & write Donald Macrae Oban

lg.l: Laogha Na Biast Bui
nach gun taoghadh gun raoghach
gun duai'ai

div.p:
20 Nov.November 1873 Thursday
Cuilean Moine given to the
minist.minister for his light to compose
his sermon.

Cl Teampul Cliamain down
on machair Hosta close to sea. A
square dyke prob.probably a church yard
round it. Teompul l.length 14½ x 8½
in centre of yard – The remains of wall
still up – Leachan Hough us
Hosta near Cill a Mhoire
an ColasayColonsay – Hough name
of place where Temple is.

lg.l: Cas eir Ulai
Chi mi mo ghaol sa Piarst
Bi an Ual agamsa nocnochd

div.p:
Na chios air chasa. Bodach
garst = scare-crow

div.title: Duan Callaig

lg.l: Nist o thainic sinn an du aichduthaich
A dh ur.dh urachadh dhuidhuibh na callaig
Cha ruig sinn lesleas bhi ga inseinnse
Bha i ann o linn ar seanar
DireDireadh air an tota & tearnatearnadh aig an dorust
Mo dhuan a ghaalghaailghabhaill gu modhail eol.eolach
Mar bu chorchoir omhdhomh
Caisein callag na mo phoca
S mor nan ceo thig on fheafhear ad
Bha suil ann gheogheobh dhedheth aile
Nach bi gu brachbrath dha fal.falain.
GheoGheobh fear an taitaigh na dhorn e
S cuircuiridh e shron anns an teallach
Theid e deiseil eir na paistean
S gu h aridaraid gheogheobh a bhean e
GheoGheobh bhean e si b' fhiach e
Lamh a riarachariarachadh na callaig
O thaing tarsttart air an duaichduthaich
Nach eil suil againn ri dram
Rud beag a thochar an t samhrasamhraidh
B fhearr sin leis an aran
Ma beilbheil sud agam rifhaotainfhaotainn
Ma dh-fhaoddh-fhaodas tu na cum mail

oirnn Mise & dorust fosgailte
(fosgail?)
"chulchulain seō challachallain seō."

div.p:
3 times went round on the
totatobhta wall of houhouse with a seice
striking it perperhaps 12 persons.

LaLatha fheill Bride peopeople went to
the traitraigh & brotbrought hohome a Partan on midmiddle
of floor. If the parstan went to uac.
aruachdar an taitaigh the man reremained on the larlaraich
an blianabliadhna, if he went to the
door he left Not now done

LaLatha ChalChaluim-chille Di daonichDi domhnaich a ChalChaluim
chaoimh &c
LaLatha Bealtain light fire
LaLatha Fheill Moire more haut harvest
shortshortly aftafter Liunastain should
be shearing & tupingtupping. LaLathafheile
Peadair sumsummer.

LaLatha-Samhna goid chail girls
put it undunder her pilpillow she saw
her lover come to take frfrom her she
was married that year 3 plates
1 of im salinsalann & uisge glan placeplaced
on floor. Person was blind folded & up
his hand in plate his death salsalann
diolanas clean water. The girls
threw their criosans out throthrough windwindow
& a blind folfolded perperson threw back one
by one the first got first man
& so on. Went to allt criche
& not to speak till she spoke to
him in her sleep – The one who came
was thetheir lover. The plate of meal
in a famine

Tilgeil ghloinneachan
clean water put in glass first &
the gealagan is let down.
If the gealgealagan rose craobhabh briabriagh
This was a port if not uisge at all
no port. SailinSalann drowning uisguisge
glan salach diol. The
du craocraobh chorc was drawn out
of teeth & acaccording – to the nonumber of grains
so of child – if top of that one
was to die – Càthadh an fhras
lin – sa cho-rachomh-rath (done at Drain
each Skye by serservant girl Her
misstressmistress asked her whom she
saw - told, well you'll have
him yet. The lady died and the girl
marmarried her master, of whom she
had no din, Salt herrings
are roasted on fire eat.eaten thirsty
the pers.person seen givggiving a drink was
the per.person to be mar.married. Co siod
shuas air ceann mo ropan
– thrown the cearsle into the
sorn of kiln The perperson who ananswered
was the perperson to marry.

Bun na CrībheCraoibhe, Valley
tree roots TraiTraigh Ghrit
west end of Vallay - large roots
also Griminish, TraiTraigh bhàn
Houghary – black mossy smol-
ogach full of tree roots

½ the seal went to Peighinn mhor
GrimGriminish 4 Pennies GrimGriminish besides
PeinnPeighinn mor 2 pennies in ScolpScolpaig
1 penpenny in KilpheadKilpheadair
I for I ChalChaluim chille Kill
i pheadpheadair grim-i-nis Scolp
a-aig – all belong to I ChaluimChaluim chille

Transcribed with No I
BBook p 196
A.Alexander A.Archibald C.Carmichael
Creagorry
8 OctOctober 1875

Odar nan ron ceann
an fhir mhoir a bha 'n GrimGiminis
Iain mac Fhearachar
ic Iveir – Iain mac Odrum
Poul ruaruadh (Maclean) Houghgerry
s mutha is a mac Odrum.

Cousmal, & scolscolpaig belong to Bal
Raail Peinn morPeighinn Mhor & Howgerry

The Cuilein Moine for minisminister by
night. CulCuilein goineachgoibhneach going out
for boat oars & the Biast
bhoireach – taken gun
modhar gun taoadhtaobhadh gun deughaidh
An average beast. Ask ArchArchibald
Macdonald Houghary why the
Biast BhoirBhoireach was given or. JonJohn
Macintosh.

In Cliatar fo thuathuath N.North Uist– a wall
beautbeautifully built appappears - abtabout 2 fathoms
visibile – LeabLeaba fhalaich Leaspu
oig Mantach at Croc-an-Fhanuis

Pollag at Cladh ChiamhuinChliamhuin Hosta
was never seen dry – alwysalways wet or moist.

Bogha an Teampuill oppopposite
Scarista beag abtabout - due EEast or
E.East N.North E.East of Northton Harris The
sea bed is over it during
low water – AbtAbout 6. ftfeet of water over
it at low water. Mr KenthKenneth
Macdonald Scarista says
that while fishing there at low water
he saw most distinctly the
walls of the buildgbuildingg throthrough the tanglstangles
are growing to a great extent over
them – tangles very long – but the
walls very distinctly seen. He saw
it to his great astonishment.
His hooks got entangled with
the long seaweed & in pulgpulling up came
the long tangles with limes shells
attached to the roots.
Langadal, small stem & large top Barr-brǎg top of staimh

BoBodha-na-Cille stones with lime
coming up with hooks. Form of a
church & circircle also torsaytorasay adha
Cladh–Baile-na-cille, the
cladh now at Scarista

Sgudh-han crosses Northton Sgriob
ruaruadh it is called, the trail of the
water horse red spots when he
was losing blood when castrat
ated – Leaca-gorstach (aite
gun tachar sam bith) the
spar strip on face of hill
east of Obbe.

BoBodha-na cille is a
good baramoter for bad weathweather
the sea "a croiceadh" up put
before a gale thothough the rest of the sea
be calm. 9 ftfeet water over the ruins
abtabout 30 ftfeet x 30 ininches runs with a small
bit connect.connected. CllearClear sand round
6 fathfathoms deep at low water

div.title: Oran Sith
div.p:
Tri feoragan 's smeor
aichean sa smeor riach
an an toiseach

lg.l: Ho a ho th' alabh gu math
halabh gu math
Cro mo mhais eir na blar
An dosg a cheann-bhaile
Am fagail tri smeoragan
3 feorg.feoragan smeoir ruaruadh
Hi ri ho ro fal gu math al gu ma

Nan bi am beul an
fhasaich.

Dhiol siod eir
a cheann dh fagdh fhag ad 3 smeog

div.p:
Siths cautcaught hold by a girl
who went for her mothmother's
cattle & kept her. Her compcompanion
got home & she sang this song

Kille-bhride name of
CladCladh Scarista – Don.Donald Mac
lennan shepshepherd to ministminister at
ScaristScarista liftlifted stones with him
up frfrom ruin of BoBodha na CillCille. It
is a large plot black with
stones & seaweed

Ri linn MhMhic AulaAmhlaigh a plaigh
camcame to Harris which cardcarried awyaway many
people. Fear drove the people in
floods to the church l holdgholding each
others hands comgcoming to church &
singsinging songs. Only 3 personpersons came
out on 33rd day. Church full of
skulls – low. Mr Angus son of Mr
AulaAulay buried opopposite the pulppulpit on NNorth side
of wall along side it.

MMaighstir AulaAmhlaidh had 6 sons 1 of these
was SgairSgaire a baker in London
MMaighstir Coinneach mistministerof Harris
then ArdnamurArdnamurchan then Caladair
air MMaighstir AonasAonghas is said
to have been ministminister of his father
CoinCoinneach Mac Onachai (Morrison)
wrote (ministminister of Harris for time) Lord
MacAulMacAulay with whose people
he had a comhaltas.
No reply.

TraiTraigh-Chaibaval
of old TraiTraigh Chliamain, betbetween –
Nisise & North-ton.
Cira = Caora (Cira fo shneachshneachd
Manx song). Brìg = Stack built
up of peats or dyke. A few
tried to stop the sea with longs
stalks & bundles of heather
in this traitraigh A gale came
& drove all his work up to
Glumag the head of the traitraigh
Sgrioba-Pheire (pe'ar)
lightning just above Sgriob
Bhan Biorghlin = broken
Thunderbolt –

lg.l: Gheall mo leannleannan dhomh sgial bhia
A ghean a meangan goid
Sa ghear am bog san ann
Saolbach dhan lamh a thu
Sheall mo bhean dhomhs eisg
Sheall siod domh trais us thiom
Dhearg mi coin dhiom ris
An bun a phris mu eiri grian
A craobh uisin tha san dorust
Tha i fo dhan chill
CuiriCuiridh mi m a'aiaghaidh air Dun-dealg
S ri i dhomh canb gun An dun
An na's Sithich fuireach

div.p:
Transcribed to II BBook
p125
A.AlexanderAArchibaldCCarmichael Creagorry
8 OctOctober 1875

Mol-na h-aoi TaoTaobh deas trees
& riasg dudubh sleamhainsleamhainn dubh all
over the stranstrand at very low
water. The swell carries away
the sand & stones & then the pplace is
black A man at TarbTarbet
built hself himselfa vessel for timber
taken from Mol na Hearadh the
mol is the strand below Alin –

Boatmen will not wear crotal
cloth. it sinks if they fall out the
stones fr.from which it is taken revenge
for taking it off them

MMaighstir AuladhAulaidh died 1760. He
& Macleod Loscintire
went to Scalpay a big day they
had made his way to the fugitive
& they were going to follow when
DonlDomhnall mac Iain oig – DonDonald
Campbell stood between sword
in hand and said that if they
went further it would be over
his body – They repaired. Ken.Kenneth
MacauyMacaulay was ministminister of Harris in
Going to Achantine AirdnamurAirdnamurchan
Mr AonasAonghas was mintminister

Size windwindow at Inn 32½ hihigh 30½ BBroad 14½
Mac 28-7 Poll 31 ch 8

Sàsag = a straw chair like the fourth
of a barrel cut out of it.

div.title: Duan na Muthairne
div.p:
Dun.Duncan Maclellan clachair Carnan
Friday 17th JanJanuary 1874

lg.l: Duan na Muthairn a RiRighna greine
S aluinaluinn do ghnuis da lub iarain
Sios rid sheisrich mhinich chnaicin
chraicinn easganan buibuidh
agus dolach no dorlach as
gach sathadh no gach sà dhin

Siod an coise cluincluinn an aon-
bheoil.

Cha do dh-fhag an aona
bhial

aon mhin-fuillich aig
a ghoirbhriach

Drollach
air tota 's fhirach air eigin
eisde ri duan na Mu'airMuthairn
Crann cruaicruaidh ris na chroch Criost
Criost cleir.cleireach as ar cionn
Dh-orduich an Dia an duil a bhann
S uas.uasal fear na h-oicheh-oidhche nocnochd
Bride chaichaidh air a ghlun
S RiRigh nan duil bha na h-uch-uchd
S lirleir omhdhomh tultulach s lirleir omhdhomh traitraigh
S lirleir omhdhomh na fir air an t snamh

S lirleir omhdhomh calpa cruinn caol
cruaicruaidh

TinnTighinn air tir gun
chairdeas ann.
S iomaiomadhgille s iomaiomadh cu
S iomaiomadh taitaigh mor air an tulaich
Gun fharmad duinduine ri cheile
Mise Mac De leig is taigh mi
Criost cleircleireach os an cionn rept

div.p: Repeated

lg.l: Mise nocnochd a tintighinn gar n ion.ionnsaidh
Dh'ur.Dh'urachadh dhuibh na Callaig
Cha ruig sin lesleas bhi ga innse
Bha e ann o linn mo sheansheanair
Dhol deis in an ardoruis
S tearnatearnadh aig an dorus

Sa an Mo dhuan aig a chom
adh

modhail eoleolach mamar
a b aineb aithne

Mo chraicion chaisein
Callaig am phoca

S mor
an ceo thig as an fheard ad
BeriBeiridh fear an taitaigh na lamh air
CuiriCuiridh e cheann anns teine teallach
CuiriCuiridhe deisildeiseil air na paisdein e
S gu seacseachd araid air bean taitaigh
Bean an taitaigh s i fhiach e
Lamh a riarriarachadh na callaig
Mar a bheil taist air an da'n
Gum bi duil againn ri drama
Rud beag a thochar an t-samht-samhraidh
Bha mi nan geall air lus an aran

Mar fhuil sid againn ri
fhaotfhatainn.

Ma dh-fhaodas
sibh na cumaibh maill
oirnn. – –

div.p:
LaLatha nam bannag ni mi dronag
Chuile te nach toir omhdhomh banag
gun sguids an fheannag an
tar diot. If they got noth
ing they piled a cairn in the
door or near it called Carn
an na mollacmollachd & then sign
out – MallacMallachd Dhia s na
Callaig agaibh
ChaiChaidh mi nocnochd dol air chalchall
dh inse mhnathmhathan a bhaile
Gur he mar LaLatha Nollaig.
When the people came
they went round the fire 3
times singsinging – Gum beanbeannaich
Dia nan taitaigh a th ann eadar
chlachan agus chrann
iomadach biabiadh & aodaich
Slainte dhaoine gu rorobh ann

lg.l: Chulaig seo challaig seo chulchulaig
ChulChulaig o chalchallaig o
A chuilig bhuibhuidh bhoicinn eir an tota bhail
an craicion Cail ca chuil

Bror an da shuil cail
eile

air on an teine bior
na gaille

div.p:
pŭth! ChulChulaig O!
chalchallaig o said the gillean
cullaig as they came to the
house.

AlastAlastair mor nam marst wswas
so small when born that plart
achunn cloicloimhe had to be placed
on eaeach side of him to get holedhold
of him in the thand. He
was as big as two men. He was
the priest of Boidsale
Boat is sunk in a hole betbetween BoisBoisdale
& KillpheadKillpheadair at Cnoch nam
Mallach disdiscovered by two of BoisBoisdale's lads
a teoradheadh each.

Duan Fir Baoghastail From RaolRaghnall Donnullach DonnullachDomhnallach
84 81 Gearrymona 3 FebFebruary 1874

A Coll womwoman had been in at Bois
dale & she told of a duan that a
Coll man compcomposed to the Laird of Coll.
They saw Iain Ruadh Mac
Mhanson comgcoming & hearhearing NieanNighean
Cholla Mor Leanach ic AlastAlastair
Baoghastail is lualuath liom cha
n brigis do mhna orst") Lady
Boisdale ran & shut the door
and told Iain RuaRuadh that he wldwould
not get in till he made a duan
such as the Collach made to her
father. So Iain RuaRuadh began

lg.l: On thainic mi chuon an duicduthaich
chan oil liom dhol a aite
A dol deisil ti a Chorneil
SanSann a d' ordan tha m laimh dhearg
Repeat
LeonLeomhann as long is bradan
Ann am bratbratach. – fir gun chealgan
Repeat
As ceant air ise smacial u air ghrin
TortToirt ordain do 1000 sluaisluaigh
B earB fhearr liom gun b fhearb fhearr ionad briabriagh
Eir nach fag.fagail bhios an tuatuath
BeantearnaBaintighearna thlacthlachd riut post
Nian boir o thu bhreacach
Nach bu tais eir chul an
Sgeul a tha brin le Clain Donl
Gu bheil an Coirileir as tir
S o tha n uacaruachdar na brataich

leig as taitaigh mi 's gu bheil mi
sgisgith."

div.p:
"S dia mhic chu leig
idh" said Boisdale.

lg.l: Nant mhios en uaister
Nach fhaifhaigh an tuatuath an sas.

div.p:
"An rorobh uthu riariamh san t Suain" said TiarnaTighearna
Ile to a man ferrying him to Barra. Sioma uair
sin. "Cuine?" "Duair bha mi am chadal."

Leac na Bana-ghoisich. The
dolmen at Kilbride. A bana ghoiseach was burnt there
Na h-Uird Bhairneach those long lint
els lying down

Cui was mar.married to NiNighean RiRigh Loch
lan lived in Dun-Crannaig (Sgeir
val.) She went eir mharac do
Lochlan to see her father – Bha
easeasan gaailgabhail fadacfadachd nach rorobh i teantighinn
He She then saw her coming & he went
to meet her toire faire e fhada
do cheile – Nan rorobh fios agadas
a liuadliuthad faothail as dol mun
chuairt a rinn mise bho na
bha sissibhse ann cha chuircuireadh tu
an u'ailumhail dhomhs fursead
mo cheile". Cū’ai the husband
(Clann na h-Ialain = Ohenleys)

The Patons in Uist are descended
from the OllaOllamh Ileach who settled
here a celebrated herbalist. (OlamhOllamh
Ileach). The cuillion that he brobrought is
Dallabrog good for cleibh druim, Am Maraich
in cairns of the strand. He had
his hohome at Dallabrog. The best watwater
for boilgboiling his lusan in brain geary
heillie.

Tobar nam buadh an Iobarta
FuairFhuair an fhuair iomal an
domhaindomhainn mhoir – fag end
of creation.

Eolas PronnaiPronnaidh – nam
faifaigh tu leagadh s droch bhun-
adh.

lg.l: An oraortha chuir Cal-cilleCalum-cille ris cois
a ghille sa ghleann
IocaiIochaidh an cneicneimhe lium
IòcaiIòcaidh an cneicneimhe deas
Iòcam ma na 3 iocann

Mar a dh-iocadh a dh Iosda
Criosta.

Nuair a chaichaidh Criost
eir a chroichchreaig bhrist cas
an eich

nar thaine CCriosta eir
ar rinn e slan a chas
Mar a rinn CCriosta slan sin

gun dean e slan seo a
uac ucuchd

an AthAthair sa Mhic
sa SpiorSpiorad Naomh (Amen)

div.p:
Seid
t anail 3 uair eir an aite
am bi an cniangan –
(the bruise). pronnadh. Ran
ald (old) vows this to be efficacefficacious
He does it still. All persons who
fall (but there must be no
cut – only a bruise) come to him
You must have faith in itse effefficacy
or else it will do you no good.
At Trossaridh Gearrynamonie
when ententingentering the road 21 yrsyears ago trees
with nuts still adhering were got
lying in the peat. They were taken
up (4 ftfeet under) brotbrought home and
& made into co ca couples.
Cniongan = a bruise so also pronnadh
from old Ranald Macdonald
OraOthra Criongain OraOthra Latin word

lg.l: An oraortha chuir Calum-cille
Ri cois a ghille sa ghleann
Iòcaidh an cneicneimhe lium
IòcaiIòcaidh an creid deas
Iòcam ma na tri Iocann
Mar a dh-iòcadh a dh-Iosta Criosta
Nuair a chai Criosta eir a {chroich{creig
Bhrist cas an eich
Nar thaine Criosta eir an lar
Rinn e slan a chas
Mar a rinn Criosta slan sin
Gun dian e slan seo
A ucuchd an Athar sa Mhic
Agus an Spioraid Naoimh.

div.p: An t-searbhag = Bitters

Dar bhios na fir chlis ard ananns
an speur & luasgainach is
e colas storm & cosal soc
airsochair ciuine. They are not seen
but in light moon light
div.add:
Aurora watched one night – seen blood red & seemgseemingly
got better– folfollowing day & rock spot-redspotted-red as if blood =

div.p:
Theid mi fhefhein suas do
chuil-bhac far nach fhaic
duine no Brianin sin. Did
so got blind & was led home
Twas to his wife he said this.
SSaint Brennans Day end of first
fortnight in SumSummer. Since then
no man in Barra would put
a spaid or soc fo thalthalamh am
Barra. The dog is kept
runrunning aftafter sheep chlippgclipping them &
sorting them. S.Saint Barr is not
now kept. S.Saint BrenBrennan is.
Ainich =

lg.l: I will pluck thee pregnant torranan

With thy pregnancy from sea & land
of the tide
At the full of the tide without turning
SSaint Bridget that foster of the
With thine own hand StSaint Bridget
SSaint Columba directing me
SSaint Oran protecting me
WhileSSaint Michael of prancing steeds
Shall infuse virtues into the Kine
I will pull thee torranan
Pregnant from sea and land
At the turn pull of the tide without change

l.del: With thine own fair hand SSaint BrdgetBridget

lg.l: StSaint Bridget with thine own fair hand.
S.SaintColumba directing me
SSaint Oran protecting me
And SSaint Michael of prancing steeds
Shall infuse virtues into the Kine

div.title: Caran mar fhithill
div.p:
Ceallach fada fiar agus aghaiaghaidh
anns san airde n iar S cha
teid i na teine am feasd

div.title: "Sea-Serpent
div.p:
I was "breacach" at dawn on Loch-
huntain close to Lew. I saw a beast
coming along towards where I was
at great speed. Bha cnap orra
& caolas eadar a chuile cnap.
They would then go down & foll.followed
eaeach other. & go fast. I thought it
was somethsomething unnatunnatural, & I felt
my Knees Knocking frfrom fear
I caught hold of the stalls of
heathheather & creep up. I thought
it could not come ashore
Its crept up in grtgreat terror. It
came ashore & what was it but
5 otters each holdholding the ottotter in
front of it by the tail. When they landlanded
they disengaged – & lay down
in a cuach (ring) in a place
evidently used ffor it. I ran
forforward again but they left on my retreturn
I got so weak that I could
hardly walk -

A grave of stones on end
in sand on wwest side of Cairnish
bay. Tree stumps at Pabbey
fireanan – a bhaile fo thuathuath –
2 ftfeet diadiameter (2 stumps) close to low
water.

Mr Aulay Macaulay
died 1760 – son of Fear Bhrein
ish a datdaughter left 15 years old. Lived
with his brobrother in law there. Mr
Hamilton at Hoy OrkOrkney His
beadle of Tormod Cleireach
came frfrom LewsLewis with Mr AulAulay
& his son the beadle died
in 1808 Mr AulAulay 3 datdaugheters
Floor WWest 7ftfeet

Caibeal Cross E Barra
4 March 1874. LLength 16x7 all 1-6 thick
Door 1-9 wide. Also Caibeal na
Meallach on a flat plain. A heap
ruins built of lime. Has been
ploughed close up & round it

Clach Mhor nan Gleann
4 MarMarch 741874 Wednesday evgevening – rough sketh perhaps of Caibeal Cross E
AvergAverage height 22 ftfeet – or thereby
Projects at north end ftfeet frfrom ground.

Two Lobsters caught by Donald
Shaw Eilean anabuich on 10th
March (Tuesday) 1874 at Loch
Seaforth (1) LLobster3 ftfeet body 18 inches
Girth 13 ininches in extension 34, large
claw circircumference 12 inches – extension
of fills 38 inches – (2) lobster
lost smaller claw & weights 6½ lbs
Weight 10½ lbs
Stavornadh = Samhla = Tāis

The wine made frfrom Sloes
is an astringent & good for diahiriadiarrhoea
So is a decoction of the root
of a plant com
mon on the mainland – not
in the island.

19 March 1874 – TuesdayThursday
At Croice – Near Bornish S.South UUist
within ½ foot low water spring
tide got the scattered ruins of a
buildgbuilding. Lime & rocks adhering
close to a rock sheltered frfrom N.North & W.West
Large heap of stones scatterscattered rounround
bent in one spot lime strongly ad
hering – Dug down a few inches &
found remains of a plant & peat
mosmoss sand & gravel then hard but
resses like broken pieces of old ruins
eleswhereelsewhere – lime running concreted
100 yrdsyards due south found several
pieces of concreted sand & pebbles – somsome
of the large cakes wiouth out – pebbles
& some full of them like pudding
stones – But these cakes are pure
sand – not like lime –

Foiriche = a mallet handle for pound
ing barley for broth.

John MacinnonMacKinnon, Dirioscal went
with food regulregulary to UaUamh Ulladail to old
Macleod of BearnBearnary. The old man DonDonald
was for the Prince & his son Norman
against the Prince. 1 yrsyears in the cave
MacinnonMacKinnon was sent with Calum
mac DhonilDhomhnaill grandfathgrandfather of MalMalcolm & Mr
Macaulays gamekeeper who had
the farm of Dirioscal. 12 yrsyears with
these family. NeiNeil was an orphan
when they took him.

lg.l: PrionsaPrionnsa Tear.Tearlach dh-falbhdh-fhalbh thar sail
Gur miosa dh-fagdh-fhag na fhuair e sin.

div.p:
Cainteag (LewsLewis & Harris) plat a bent
of bent
Gearagaal = a good grazing a feeding place

Near Airdsleave large lake
John Morrison's father grground officer
father told him during hard frost
the thick ice on lake was broken
right throothrough & a pathway made frfrom
shore to island – must have
been made by animal 40
yrsyears ago. Woman saw
among her cattle 1 morgmorning an
animal grey long hair longer
than a cow's ababout size of a
foal or 1 yryear colt. Round hoof
like a horse with a spin down
into ground behind hoof. A gentle
man of Campbell living at
Airdshleave a scholar saw
it & also told John Morrison. Never saw
such an animal. What could
it be Any time seen seen abtabout
this lake & the largest in Harris
except Lochlangabhat – Spin
going down 1 inch in ground

Great Fight
during the hergherring fishfishing of CharCharles II – boats
arrived with drink frfrom Uist Pabby
sold in exchange for hergherring. Those
frfrom east called aftafter Leith & all frfrom WWest
CampbeltonCampbeltown – fotfought & many kildkilled
on both sides & buried in Neartey
ey Sarstey CheesbayCheesebay – from
all parts of Britain The south
CampbeltonCampbeltown peoppeople won – Huarsay
Ortersay. Heamartry Ta'ey – the
isle in which the peoppeople were buried.
Some were buried under cover
by night – No hergherring aftafter this Also
frfrom Ireland – end of centcentury; fishgfishing be
gan From JonJohn Morrison Lingriva

Bearnarey – A poor man Norman
MacPhairc (Park) got at low
water at. Riff a razor-fish with a
pearl inside.

"Eilean an Du-chonnaidh"
formerly an island now the strand
with two pyramidal remnants
of moss standing over the clam
shingle near Creagorry – between
the point of Aird an Eoin and
Hacleit – Du-chonnaidh is
fresh or green brush wood – Men
living who this isle large.

div.title: Bittern
div.p:
Found at Milton 17th March 1874 – at
in a gravel pit at roadside within
a gunshot of Flora Macdonald's gravehouse
foutfought like a buck & squealed like
a pig ruff about neck stood
out as a lady said like an ElizaElizabethan
collar. ServtServant said the bird was
unlucky & an evil omen & so when
the people got up in the morning the bird
was dead & eaten up by the cats. And
the bird of the same kind said
to have been shot it by a shepshepherd near
the same place a four years
ago & also Bailanloin N.North Uist
Geadhail = Large field

lg.l: "Dun Bhuiri na theine Dun BhBhuiri na theine
Gun chu gun duine gun daoine"

div.title: An t-Each Uisge
div.p:
Thainig e gu taitaigh iasgair. Bha bhean
shishith agus prais lit aice. Bha eise
ga thiormachadh fhein 's a lamh-
an fliuch an deideigh titighinn as a mhuir.
Co ainm tha ort ors a bhean shishith
Mise s mi fhein, Mine nam fear
fir far na coite bogai mise an
lit ad Bog bog a ghaoil
Thilg i lan an ladair dhan lit
ma'n chamag aige. Leum e mach
a sgriadail. Co bha riut orsa mhac
Mi fhefhein s mi fhefhein nam bu duine
eile gun deandeanadh, 's mise gur
dioladh. Thoir fios thun
bean a chragain lite tha mo
chrioslach eir a losgadh

Tree roots 15 ftfeet long & 1½ diamdiameter. em
bedded in peat at Rubhŏisinis
Bearnary Harris. Tasgal
Macthasgail cut these trees In
Pabbay Ruch nis now an isle
tree roots there and lobsters sheltering
in their crevices. Trees fallen also at
Tao a bhaile-fo-thuaTaobh a bhaile-fo-thuath a in a storm. Close
fathers of men now living (1873) saw
corn growing where now land is seen
only at low water between isle & PabbyPabbay
proper. Man made a house in
Seana Chaisteal & discover opengopening
undrunder his foot. He opened it & made
some nice sleeping apartapartments & keep
ing places in the recesses.
(Cha n ordan oicheoidhche e – Nan rorobh seo agam)

Thainig na sithechean feadh
na h oicheoidhche agus dh eubh ad "Circ card
adh cuigealadh – Fair 'uinn
obair ra dhiana ri linn dhuit dragh
a chuir oirnn. Bha sinne le maist
irmaighstir gus na chuir sinn fearg eir."
Sann an Croc nan claigeann ann
Boradh Bearnaray bha seo

Buachaile faire bhana san TaoTaobhtuatuath
Cuireadh a' cro an ura sheoil gu Li
bhuail (?) bhl Bhuail i fead
leum an crocrodh sios an traitraigh sa mach
eir a mhuir. Bha 3 ba len 3 laoilaoigh
dol thar CheiligraigCheiligraigh. Thilg an duine
lan a chroigh 'n pholl orra bha fo
chois dheis orra. Stad seo an bho bha
eir dheireadh leis a n laogh chuag
adh.

A man in S.South Uist had a
no.number of horses among which a fine
colt came home. The horses
were blowing trumpets & ran
home frightened by this horse.
He looked & saw the colt & had
to chase it away but could not.
He then cautcaught hold of its m
muing & it was full of raf-
agaich & sand. He turned him
away & the beast went away towards
the lake. "an aon t sian
aige" – & went into the lake.
Nan rorobh mismise air am
beannachadh sa mhad
uinn s Buachaile Chalum
chille gradh bhi sinn mu an
cuairt dluth a ra said his in the morning
wife no beast would come
near them.

div.title: Cro Mara
div.p:
Bha banntrach ann an eilean iom
allach s goirid on cladcladach Bha
i deanadeanamh curraccurrach faisg eir a
mhuir. Bhatar a gichnich
ura s cha rorobh i tuigsintuigsinn co bha
ris idir. S bha fios aice nach rorobh
crocrodh aice fhefhein ris. ChaiChaidh i sin
far gu tir mor far an rorobh sean
duine. Fuirich ag aire ors easeasan
oicheoidhche no fad seacseachdainn gus am faic
uthu co bha ris. Rinn i sin agus
oicheoidhche do na h-oichh-oidhcheannan chunchunnaic i a
grunangrunnan chruichruidh a dull on mhuir
agus a ga'ailgabhail dhan arararbhar. GhaGhabh
i man cul s chuir s stigh
dhan chuir ad gus an cum
ail ann gu madmaduinn. Bha
le nach fac i an seorsa
cruicruidh riariamh. Air eagal ga'n tug neach sam bibith uaibhuaipe
ad dh' fhuadaichdh' fhair i nam burb urrainn
na dha roiroimhe dhan oicheoidhche. Am
briste na faire chual i
bhi g euacheughach. Thug i suil s
chunnaig i boirboireannach - an dara
leth na boirboireannach s an leleth eile na
h-iasg falt fada min ruaruadh oirre
Orsa a mhaighdeann mhara.
Siceir bricein donnach
guailean bo dhudhubh bo dhonn
bo chrom ria'achriabhach sliocsliochd
na h-aona bha maoile ruairuaidhe
nach do dh'fagdh'fhag buaile riariamh
na h-aonan (gu'n siol
bhi orra-siolach) blarag
o hao s blarag ho ro taratarbh
mogach donn a lesachleasach
leum tharr gara na
cuir an crodh mach
air deoin a bhoirbhoireannaich gha cead
s is air thus – cha n fhacas
riariamh tuill aidiad s cha do chchuireadh
dragh sinair aaarbhar na
banntraich riariamh tuille.
From DunDuncan Maclellan (Ban) Carnan 5 May 741874

Sithein at Canna & when the
men left their plough irons then
at night they found them
in the morning dressed so
said an old man who used
to do this.

Baileshear 7 April 1875
Wednesday
Fionaghal (Nic Chalum) Macleod

snaisniamh

air an cura ma
seach

cneicneimh ri cneicneimh

fuil
ri fuil

cracein ri
cracein

gaois
eid ri gaoisedgaoiseid

mar a leisleighis
CCriosd mac De sin gur h ann a
leibhis e seo orsta 3 times said

div.p:
Carran lin (lin glas gun ghuil
acghuileachd) was twisted into thread. A knot
was put on one end first then midmiddle
then other end to the snailesnaithle
put round the affaffected joint.

BBook III p. 175

div.title: OraOrtha rinn Moire
div.p:
dha na chailchaillich bhocbhochd eir
urlar a ghlinnghlinne chuir i
im ri sheile (a spit) gu
meudeachadh a him s
gu luad.luadhachadh a bainne. 3 times
said an ainainm an AAthair s MhMhic
san SpSpiorad naomh.

Transcribed into
BBook III p. 176

div.title: Snaile

lg.l: Ni mis air obair ri shuil
A ucuchd PheadPheadair a ucuchd Phoil
A ucuchd Phadra mhin na feaist
Is gach math ga math gan tig
Ga be rinn a t suil dhuit
Gun till i eir fhein
Gun till eir a dhaoine
Gun till eir a spreispreidh
Eir a chaillich mhiongaich
Mhangaich bheur-luirg
Dh-eirich sa mhaduin

A suil na seilbh a seilbh
na toin
Nar a lethi le a buaile fhein

A chuid nach ich na fith
ich dhi
gun ich na h eoin i
4 rinrinn an t suil dhuit.

div.p:
Fear agus bean gill & nieannighean
3 eile thileas e AAn t AthAthair s mac
agus an SpiordSpiorad naomh.

Anothers – Goes ere sunrise
to a well where the living & the dead
pass – a spring that does not
dry. She puts the cuman sun-
wise round the well & strikes the
botbottom on the water say an ainm an
Ar.Athair sa MhiMhic san SpSpiorad nnaomh amen.
This is done 3 times. She then
lifts a small quantquantity of water
a glassful will suffice. Then
3 leugagan beaga bronach & through
the 3 from the edge or botbottom of the
well. She throws on over the
guala thoisgeul left saying
Rosad usagus farmad na bhas
deoideoghaidh a bheo'aichbheothaich (no'n duine)
sin a slailaigh eir aan siod. She then
brings home the 2 other & silver
(1/-) (6d is broken money & will not
do) or a brooch in the water
which she brigsbrings home sprinkles
it on the animal saying an
ainm an ArAthair sa Mhic san
SpSpiorad NNaoimh. The illness then
leaves (a greim?) the sick
and goes to the expert which
makes her sick & vomiting
for 24 hours. She wldwould re-
quire to be well paid – some
thing must be given her – even
a pin.

lg.l: CuirCuiridh mise sian a bheatha bhuain
Eir ar crocrodh leannleathann lair
Air creagan eir an lailaigh am beo'achbeothach

Gun eirich e suas le buaibuaidh
le beannacbeannachd

Gun suil gun druth
Gun fharmfharmad

SuthaSughaidh mismise
a seo sù feith farmad

eir suil bhig san suil
mhoir eir ceanartceannard an

taitaigh san teolaichteoghlaich acasan
GuanGun eirich gach droch bhuil s gach droch bhuaibhuaidh
bha riubhse ma mhol-mhollaich
brat sibh bheanbheannaich cricridhe sibh
tiundanam us teandanam
eir an cai caoirecaora boirean
eir an laoilaoigh fhirean eir

Then follows LaLatha dhomhs
mi dol dhan Roimh &c.
